qas.question: What is the goal of Theravada Buddhism?

answers.text: the attainment of the sublime state of Nirvana
practicing the Noble Eightfold Path (also known as the Middle Way)
a state wherein one remains in this cycle to help other beings reach awakening

qas.question: What is the goal of Tibetan Buddhism?

answers.text: by practicing the Noble Eightfold Path

qas.question: In what buddhism is the goal a state of nirvana?
What buddhism has a goal of Buddhahood or rainbow body?
The Noble Eightfold Path is also known as what?
Mahayana aspires to Buddhahood through what path?

context: In <a5_0>Theravada<a5_0/> Buddhism, the ultimate goal is <a0_0>the attainment of the sublime state of Nirvana<a0_0/>, achieved <a4_0>by <a1_0>practicing the Noble Eightfold Path<a4_0/> (also known as <a7_0>the Middle Way<a7_0/>)<a1_0/>, thus escaping what is seen as a cycle of <a9_0>suffering and rebirth<a9_0/>. Mahayana Buddhism instead aspires to Buddhahood via the <a8_0>bodhisattva<a8_0/> path, <a2_0>a state wherein one remains in this cycle to help other beings reach awakening<a2_0/>. <a6_0>Tibetan<a6_0/> Buddhism aspires to <a3_0>Buddhahood or rainbow body<a3_0/>.
